caption: Great space hosting 1-2 exhibitions at a time. And for anyone who is a photographer or appreciates photography it is a must to visit the foundation of the father of the “decisive moment” and one of the greatest photographers.

Unique location hidden from the parisien touristic mess. Just next to the heart of Le Marais, the foundation makes temporal expositions of young and consolidated photographers across its 2 floors + the space dedicated to the Cartier-Bresson photo archive. I do recommend it and also visiting the shop just in the entrance of the atrium!
Nice space… Interesting seeing the prints from the ‘The Decisive Moment’ book.

A nice place to visit and see photographs, however I was very disappointed that it didn’t showcase more of Bresson’s work. There were only about five of his photographs, including his most famous ones. The exhibition at the time was good but I expected to see more of Bresson’s work.
Small exquisite museum of photography in the Marais showing original HCB  and many contemporary photographs - worth a detour

Interesting photography exhibits. I’m sure it depends on who they are showcasing. Beautiful facility, not too crowded, but quite a few people. We wished there were more photos by Cartier-Breslin. They should have a permanent exhibit of his work.
They had a wonderful exhibit on Bresson's work on China after World War II during my visit.
Such amazing exhibits, and the story telling of the rooms is art in itself
A pure delight unfortunately way too small for photography lovers and Cartier Bresson fans.

Though it's a small museum they often have several exhibitions. The exhibition I wanted to see today was in one hot stuffy overcrowded and not really well ventilated room in the basement. You have to pay the entrance fee for the whole museum so it was quite a rip-off. They use the fact that they are located in the Marais. I would not recommend it.
Great photo museum with solid good photographie. Changing exhibitions, so check the website. You can not take your elephant in though.
Few photographs by The Great Master but an interesting space for other collections

As lots of reviews have already mentioned, there is no comprehensive and permanent exhibition of Cartier Bresson here. I really think this needs to be made more apparent to visitors... it's right at the bottom of the "Visit Us" page on the website.  Having said that, I really enjoyed the exhibition of photos of Ruth Orkin's bicycle trip across the US. Interesting and thought provoking, especially the shot where she purposely blocks the view of the Lincoln Memorial with her pushbike.

Say btw 3 and 4 stars:  nice space dedicated to award winning photographers  I would put a few more photos of Henri C Bresson and Martine F and a more furnished library (maybe more services as small bar) reach five stars.
Made a brief stop to check an exhibition. Cool, spacious, and welcoming venue.
They showed two smallish photo exhibitions, plus a few prints of HCB’s works. They were both interesting, but I had expected a much larger place with more HCB work on show.
Where the Eye of the Century and his wife lived together
Beautiful, well crafted, a must-see if you’re a photo lover.
Quite disappointing, there is only one room of the museum plus another small one of an exhibition. In addition, it's quite expensive, 9€ per person.

I am not recommend to visit this place because it’s waste time and money, the ticket costs 9€, there is only one room with some  photos of HCB, he has lot of photos I don’t understand why they are not there

Nice gallery if you are interested in photography. I was a bit disappointed not to see more works by Henry Cartier Bresson but the exhibits were very good and informative. Go to see photography but don't expect to see the classic HCB photos.

August 2019. I visited on a weekend morning during the Wright Morris exhibit. It was one of the most memorable and enjoyable museum visits I had in Paris. I loved the space and the curation of Morris’ work. Great selection of (mostly Magnum) photography books as well. Really well done!
beautiful exhibition hall and museum for all lovers of photography and art. In a fantastic neighbourhood.
Best photography museum, along with la MEP. Exceptional Stephen Shore exhibition
I was hoping to see his photos, i’ve been studying his art for 20 years, came to PARIS, for the first time and they show only 5 photos and the rest is from another photographers. VERY DESSAPOINTED

I’ve been a fan of HCB for many years and his work has been incredibly influential on mine. So it was a treat to visit. It’s a small intimate space with changing exhibits. However, I was not impressed with the quality of the prints. I’ve seen his original prints (at least those made under his direction in his later years and also that were signed) and the ones for the exhibit looked like they had been scanned from the original negatives and printed recently. These have a different look than the Agfa Brovira paper used in the 1970’s. There there also no early vintage prints (from the 1930’s etc) which would have been small and made primarily for book and magazine reproductions In addition these images are too clean and all imperfections had been removed as though in Photoshop (dust, scratches etc). Finally, some of these are also printed quite muddy in tones. Still a worthwhile stop for those interested in photography.
Small place with 2 interesting exhibits

We saw a good expo of photography in China 1948 and 1958 (there seems to be just the expos, no permanent exhibition). The price was a bit steep considering the size of the display (a couple of large rooms), but the labelling was detailed and bilingual, so kudos for that

If you’re coming to see photos by Cartier Bresson, there are like three and a few others by his wife. The special exhibit on men’s bodies made it hard to keep my lunch down and the exhibit of the women who crossed the U.S. with a bicycle had a strong smell of a set up. Other than that…

Enjoyable little photography exhibition space on three floors  in an out of the way part of town. English laminated translations of the photographer information are available and the photograph labels are in French. There is a little gift shop on the ground floor. The exhibit wasn't crowded and good value at €8.  Don't visit expecting Cartier Bresson. I imagine his works are in grander museums around the world. When I visited the works exhibited were by Polish photographer Zbigniew Dlubak.
Exhibition were nice but the galery is quite small. Will take you around 30 minutes to visit it.

Very disappointing, made a pilgrimage across town to see the great mans work only to find out there is very few of his prints on display. With the huge array of galleries in Paris your euros can be spent more wisely elsewhere.
Good place to swing by if you’re in the neighbourhood. Ten euros is a bit too expensive to me because it only had two exhibitions. The parallel one was interesting.
If you love photography you must stop here, even if just to look at the books. 8€ to enter and very inspiring. One of my favorite things we did in Paris!
Wonderful photographic bookshop and a smallish gallery that always hosts some of very best photographic exhibitions in the city. A fine tribute to the master.

As a street photography lover I made a pilgrimage visit to this museum. I suppose this should be a must go place for any street photographers visiting Paris. However, the museum is a total scam. Only very few work of HCB is being displayed, and they are presented in a tiny room (about 250 square feet, equivalent to a large hotel room), and they call this a museum. The most famous work of HCB is not even shown. Almost half of the space of the “museum” is dedicated to the work of another photographer (who captured some random shots of the streets in Africa). Great. To justify for the high price I paid for visit, I circulated the room twice, hoping desperately to find a magical doorway that might perhaps lead to a larger show room. Last but not least, I found it ridiculous to see there is more of HCB’s work on the postcards sold in the Museum’s souvenir shop than the actual exhibition..... MFS!!!

Very disappointing. Only part of one room to see. I first heard of Henri Cartier Bresson at an exhibit 5 years ago at the Pompidou Centre, which was fabulous.  Knowing how much of his work is available, I had high expectations of this place.
The place is small, maybe too small associated to this huge name. Nevertheless they show selected artists and it's worth stopping by. Be aware: this place does not show HCB photographs!
